message.content:
cs.IT, cs.DM, cs.NI, cs.SI, cs.CC. 

The paper deals with information transmission and processing in a network, which is a common theme in the Information Theory (cs.IT) and Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-categories. The use of random graphs and analysis of their properties suggests that the paper may also belong to the Discrete Mathematics (cs.DM) sub-category. The study of Boolean processing functions and their impact on the ability to reconstruct the original bit suggests that the paper may also belong to the Social and Information Networks (cs.SI) sub-category. Finally, the use of explicit constructions and algorithmic techniques suggests that the paper may also belong to the Computational Complexity (cs.CC) sub-category.
